docs.lead_paragraph: A bankruptcy court judge has rejected the reorganization plan filed by the Coram Healthcare Corporation and a related company, Coram Inc., with the support of lenders holding its principal debt, the company said yesterday. The announcement did not cite a reason for the judge's rejection, and the company said it was not prepared to elaborate. As filed, the plan would have given all of Coram's equity to its debt holders and left nothing for shareholders. Coram said its operating units had continued operating as usual, had maintained positive cash flow and had kept current with trade creditors. Coram sought protection in August because it could not make payments on $251 million in debt due or redeemable in May 2001.

headline.main: JUDGE REJECTS CORAM HEALTHCARE REORGANIZATION PLAN

docs.abstract: Bankruptcy court judge rejects reorganization plan filed by Coram Healthcare Corp (S)
docs.snippet: A bankruptcy court judge has rejected the reorganization plan filed by the Coram Healthcare Corporation and a related company, Coram Inc., with the support of lenders holding its principal debt, the company said yesterday. The announcement did not...

docs.lead_paragraph: After 25 years as one of New Jersey's most adept behind-the-scenes players, Donald T. DiFrancesco, president of the State Senate, stepped forward today as the governor-in-waiting after Gov. Christie Whitman was selected by President-elect George W. Bush to become administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. At a news conference at the municipal building in his hometown, Mr. DiFrancesco, a Republican, said he was ready to step into the job he has desired for years and will run for next November, seeking a full term.

headline.main: 'Regular Jersey Guy' Steps In, And He Plans to Stay Awhile

docs.abstract: Donald T DiFrancesco, president of New Jersey Senate, steps forward as governor-in-waiting after Gov Christie Whitman is selected to become administrator of Environmental Protection Agency; Di Francesco says he is ready for job he has desired for years, and will run next November, seeking full term as governor; assures New Jerseyans that he can handle concurrent responsibilities of being Senate president and acting governor; photo (M)

byline.original: By ROBERT HANLEY with ANDREW JACOBS

docs.section_name: Front Page; Washington; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: For 35 years, Dr. Stuart Copperman was one of the most prominent and trusted physicians in this tightknit community on Long Island's South Shore. The onetime president of the Nassau Pediatric Society, he was a familiar figure at his temple, a man who saved the lives of neighborhood children, a doctor whom former patients took their children and grandchildren to. But this month the State Health Department revoked his license because of allegations that he molested some of his teenage patients from 1978 through 1989. Six women whom he had seen as teenagers testified against him, telling similar stories. And since the doctor's license has been revoked, department officials say, dozens more have stepped forward saying he molested them during examinations when they were girls.

headline.main: Conflicting Images of Pediatrician in Molestation Case

docs.abstract: Two young women repeat their accusations that Dr Stuart Copperman molested them in his office in Merrick, LI, during physical exams he gave them when they were girls; he denies charges and is appeal revocation of his license; State Health Department says that since license was revoked, dozens more women have come forward with similar accusations against Copperman; other patients voice support for Copperman; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Everything important about Central Clinical Hospital is contained in a single fact: its Granovsky Street address, almost in the shadow of the Kremlin. This was the hospital of the Communist elite, where the best Soviet doctors labored to reverse Leonid Brezhnev's sclerosis, to save Yuri Andropov's failing kidneys, to prolong Konstantin Chernenko's labored breaths.

headline.main: Capitalism Comes to Russian Health Care

docs.abstract: Article in series Freedom's Toll, about decline in Russian life expectancy and health care system, describes Meditsina, private clinic in Moscow where wealthy Russians get up-to-date Western-style care, for a price; ten-story complex staffed by Russian doctors and American advisers has CAT scanner, imported steel operating room and will soon get laptops and Internet connections in every room; photos; Russians are steeped in notion of free care, but future of medicine in their country seems to be first-class private system sprouting between weathered cracks of fifth-class public one (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Israel Admits Killings Of Palestinian Militants Senior Israeli officials have acknowledged a new tactic of hunting down and killing individuals whom Israel holds responsible for planning or making attacks on its citizens. The disclosures have provoked an outcry among Palestinian officials, who call such actions ''state terrorism.'' A12 Shimon Peres, a former prime minister and a Nobel Peace laureate, lost his short-lived bid to run for prime minister when the leftist Meretz Party voted against endorsing him. A12
